name: Willem Pienaar
bio: I build AI tools and open source communities. Previously led engineering teams @TectonAI, built the ML platform at @gojektech, and created @feast_dev.

activity.text: RT @SnowflakeDB: Feature Stores in the Age of Generative AI and LLMs with the Creator of Feast #dataheroes https://t.co/iwhNdywcGq

Can generative AI remove all grunt work from software engineering? I'm working with some folks who think so.

I‚Äôve put down some thoughts over at Agentik https://t.co/KMpvSBzXGh, and I‚Äôll be sharing more over the coming weeks.

Super excited to be speaking at the LLMs in Production conference. We're just one day out!

A really stacked lineup with @matei_zaharia @chipro @RazRazcle @tristanzajonc @aparnadhinak @ajratner @ShreyaR @mistercrunch @TreybigDavis @doppenhe and many more!

https://t.co/KoiPYyZxsV https://t.co/YQmf0GrAwY

Had a blast working with @shrumm and the team over at @weights_biases to help fill out this course on "Building LLM-Powered Applications"!

Great content for folks that are serious about building production-grade AI applications! Check out the section on https://t.co/xDnYDFKHcB!

quoted.text: üéâ I'm thrilled to announce we're launching a free online course at @weights_biases, titled "Building LLM-Powered Applications." This course is designed for Machine Learning practitioners and Software Engineers who are interested in understanding LLMs and wish to use them in‚Ä¶ https://t.co/I7XhoqIryQ

@willpienaar I understand; I just mean the client-code (invocation) will still reside on a server in most scale-out architectures.

replyTo.text: @jeffrschneider "Fat" here just means that the logic is client side vs server side. It's still only going to be a few lines of code and very lightweight.

activity.text: @jeffrschneider Correct

replyTo.text: @willpienaar I understand; I just mean the client-code (invocation) will still reside on a server in most scale-out architectures.

activity.text: @willpienaar cool. The fat client will likely be deployed in a serverless env. (lambda, etc.)  - so not too fat, or can't use it. Other popular LLM projects fail this test and are unusable for cheap scale-out.

replyTo.text: @jeffrschneider Depends. If you run the heuristic and vector database checks, it should be pretty fast. The LLM check is slow of course. We'll soon have fat clients for TS/JS and Python that doesn't require a service. That should be much leaner overall.

activity.text: @jeffrschneider "Fat" here just means that the logic is client side vs server side. It's still only going to be a few lines of code and very lightweight.

activity.text: RT @hwchase17: As more LangChains make their way into production, we're getting more questions about the security and privacy of these syst‚Ä¶

When Rebuff detects an attack, it stores the attack signature in a database of learned attacks, and uses that signature to prevent future attacks!

You can try out the managed version in our playground: https://t.co/cvl1XEszeu

Or deploy it yourself: https://t.co/uftr5ULXmJ

4/4

replyTo.text:
However, we believe that AI builders still need security in place while we work to solve the problem.

Rebuff adds that security through 4 layers of defense:
1. Heuristic checks
2. LLM based checks
3. Similarity based checks on known attacks
4. Canary word leak detection

3/4

2. The shift to custom models for specific tasks
3. How in-house training may not be necessary for most teams
4. The role of humans in prompt creation
5. How soon we'll get to AGI

activity.text: Exactly the kinds of discussions we should be having if we're to move from toy AI applications to reliable production systems. @hwchase17 and his team are on a roll!

Super exciting to see @hwchase17 and the contributors at @LangChainAI  incorporate emergent techniques into their framework so quickly!

Contextual compression is just one of many low hanging fruit in boosting the accuracy and relevance of generations. Loads more to come soon!

quoted.text:

We introduce multiple new methods in @LangChainAI to compress retrieved documents w.r.t. the query before passing to an LLM for generation

Inspired by @willpienaar at the "LLMs in production" conference

activity.text:
AutoGPT aka Skynet? 

This is a real GitHub issue:

"Auto-GPT decided on it's own that it wanted to create an AI model on its own, and started doing so. Even ignoring my CRTL+C attempts and just kept going."

https://t.co/YTTK1SckEy

So is Chain of Thought prompting already redundant?

At first glance it seems so, but in my experiments RCI prompting can push an LLM into an "apology loop" where it keeps second guessing itself. 

The efficacy of RCI still seems very use case dependent.

quoted.text:
LLM Agents Can Recursively Criticize & Improve Outputs

-Simple prompt to review & improve can beat:
Reinforcement Learning
Supervised Learning
CoT prompting

-Only needs a few demos per task, rather than thousands
-No task-specific reward function needed

https://t.co/Ec0x86jXb0 https://t.co/I9W9ZFkURf

activity.text: The situation with $SIVB is not about a handful of wealthy individuals who bet on risky assets and lost money. In fact I‚Äôd argue that those people are barely affected. It‚Äôs about thousands of companies not being able to pay tens of thousands of employees.  Aüßµ

@MathesonZander @atShruti @kirbywinfield @chudson @abrams @kentlind @TaylorJHolland @jasoncwarner @emaxerrno @galenward @mistercrunch @anna_fil Crazy times. @bytewax is lucky to have you at the helm @MathesonZander.

activity.text: Latency is a huge problem for folks building AI products on LLMs. https://t.co/P07qZm7Frt
The amount of calls quickly balloon when using techniques (like DEMONSTRATE‚ÄìSEARCH‚ÄìPREDICT) that require multi-hop workflows.

activity.text: Playing around with ChatGPT and other LLMs over the last couple months, I've found myself spending a lot of time copy-pasting content from websites and converting it to plain text.

replyTo.text: @AbeGong How accurate does it need to be for your use case @AbeGong ? Trafilatura seems to be a pretty accurate middle ground, and use Justext. It has also been integrated into @gpt_index.

activity.text: It seems like the logical next step is PKI and digital certificates (X.509) for AI generated content, assuming  watermarks can somehow be made durable.

quoted.text:
I was very skeptical of GPTZero that claims to detect human vs ChatGPT output. Now I‚Äôm more convinced after seeing this LLM watermark algorithm @tomgoldsteincs. If OpenAI deploys something like this, then GPTZero will do a *much* better job.

Brace yourself, high-schoolers!

1/ https://t.co/mS2JDRVAUY

activity.text: Anybody have a best practices guide on decoupling data loading, preprocessing, the model, the training loop, and serving? Specifically, for pytorch models, and ideally huggingface (so don't come at me with TFX)

@eprosenthal @eprosenthal depending on the type of data loading and preprocessing, some of this logic can be upstreamed into a feature store. Do you have a PyTorch repo that I can update to illustrate?

replyTo.text: Back to the original question, I feel like all of this _can_ be solvable for a specific model, but I'd love to see some generic best practices (e.g. "Datasets should preprocess but be agnostic of the data source, so you should pass in a function to load the data in __init__()")

activity.text:
Great question from the @LocalOptimistic slack - how do you stay technical as a manager? Does it matter?

My answer - I constantly worry about not being technical enough

An unorganized thread for my unorganized system.

@eugeneyan @vboykis @teej_m I'm also curious.

I've entered a few small groups (5-8 people) where we exchange ideas and learnings, but the members focus on the same domain. That leads to depth in learning, not breadth. It seems like the difference in the above mentorship is that it's 1:1 and spans domains.

replyTo.text: @vboykis @teej_m This is new to me and I'm intrigued. Would either of you be able to share some pointers on how you got started please?

activity.text:
RT @chipro: After my post on real-time machine learning last year, many people asked me how to do it.

This post discusses the challenges +‚Ä¶

After my post on real-time machine learning last year, many people asked me how to do it.

This post discusses the challenges + solutions for online prediction, online evaluation, and continual learning, with use cases and examples.

Feedback appreciated!

https://t.co/lywDVpYnUD

@chipro Very well written @chipro!

As @jayparth_ said, most ML teams see feature stores as the solution to real-time feature computation and serving. @TectonAI supports most classes of streaming computation today, and we're actively working on a streaming compute engine for @feast_dev.

replyTo.text:

This post discusses the challenges + solutions for online prediction, online evaluation, and continual learning, with use cases and examples.

https://t.co/lywDVpYnUD

activity.text:
@chipro @jayparth_ @TectonAI @feast_dev In terms of log-and-wait: It's simple to implement and many teams have had success with it. The key downside is the inability to compute/backfill new features for model training.

Have you seen teams rely on log-and-wait if they aren't serving very large amounts of traffic?

replyTo.text:
@chipro Very well written @chipro!

As @jayparth_ said, most ML teams see feature stores as the solution to real-time feature computation and serving. @TectonAI supports most classes of streaming computation today, and we're actively working on a streaming compute engine for @feast_dev.

activity.text:
You can get events to Cloud Run services with:

1- Eventarc AuditLog trigger
2- Eventarc Pub/Sub trigger 
3- Pub/Sub direct. 

How do you decide which one to use? Check out my article:

https://t.co/TiLwp5JISS
@meteatamel Looking forward to it. I think it will be a major unlock for Cloud Run.

replyTo.text: @willpienaar No. Eventarc only supports Google Cloud event sources right now. However, 3rd party sources are on the roadmap.

activity.text: @github The new Discussions feature is pretty neat, but is there a reason why discussions aren't indexed by search engines? cc @tweetsbyevi

this weekend i read about feature stores to better understand (1) what they are and (2) how they can be a valuable part of the ML stack

i've learned that feature stores help standardize the interface between models and data. this standardization is valuable in many dimensions üëá

@adamlaiacano @jeremyjordan I think it's ultimately unavoidable if the feature store is the layer between models and data. If a goal is to commoditize model serving then the model or the feature store should have at least some request-time transformations.

replyTo.text: @jeremyjordan Some things like Zipline (and I think Tecton?) put aggregations right into the feature store. It‚Äôs clever but I am sure it can and will be pushed to the max by MLEs.

activity.text: - how do you experiment with the addition of new features? do you populate a "research" namespace which is only used for offline (non-production) exploration?

replyTo.text:
i'm excited to dig deeper into this topic! some questions i still have:

- do you populate feature stores with only "raw" features and leave derived features (e.g. interaction terms) for post-processing before model predictions? https://t.co/qT8dxEhPHU

activity.text: @jeremyjordan I've seen teams use a "sandbox" project/namespace for general purpose development. Other teams create dedicated dev namespaces per project. We're working on new functionality for Feast where experimentation doesn't require a namespace to be registered at all (local only).

replyTo.text: - how do you experiment with the addition of new features? do you populate a "research" namespace which is only used for offline (non-production) exploration?

activity.text: @jeremyjordan In general we encourage teams to pre-compute (derive) features as much as is possible. Of course this wont work in all cases. Storage costs can balloon for certain kinds of feature computations, and some features depend on request-level inputs.

replyTo.text:
i'm excited to dig deeper into this topic! some questions i still have:

- do you populate feature stores with only "raw" features and leave derived features (e.g. interaction terms) for post-processing before model predictions? https://t.co/qT8dxEhPHU
